content: this scarf draws inspiration from the chevron patterns prevalent in knit sweaters and various non-knit garments of the 1930s and 40s combining both a sportive and elegant look in addition the incorporation of stripes lends itself to a make do and mend project this makes it perfect for utilizing leftover yarn that have been sitting in your stash for far too long the size of the stripes and the number of colors can be adjusted to your personal taste and to the amount of yarn available the chevron pattern is created solely through the use of increases and decreases larger needles were chosen for this project than those normally recommended for this type of yarn given that garter stitch knitting can become dense and tight the use of bigger needles creates a softer and airier fabric ~~~~~~~~~~ this scarf is made entirely from leftover yarn embracing the make do and mend mindset feel free to do the same alternatively some yarn options are listed below that were or can be used for this scarf in case you prefer to purchase specific materials for the project yarn option 1 as used for sample filcolana alva 50g = 350 m 2 strands held together 100% alpaca yarn option 2 drops nord 50 g = 170 m 45% alpaca 30% polyamide 25% wool yarn option 3 lana grossa ecopuno 50 g = 215 m 72 % cotton 17 % merino wool 11 % alpaca or any other yarn that fits the range of lace- fingering- and sport-weight yarns ~~~~~~~~~~ **techniques** german twisted cast on method increasing and decreasing binding off **gauge** 22 stitches / 10 cm & 44 row / 10 cm in garter stitch knit flat **size** width 12 5 cm length adjustable to personal preference **yarn quantity** depending on your personal preference 75g of yarn will give you approximately 162 cm in length **needles** 4 5 mm for knitting
